Situation1: Be patient and understanding of each other's differences.
Expectation2: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation2: A client has an inquiry about a specific line item on their most recent invoice.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from my younger brother, Sam, just as I was about to call a client back. He was upset, venting about how I never listen to his side of things when we argue. I could almost hear his frustration in the text, and I knew he expected me to be patient, to show him the respect he deserved as my sibling. But at that moment, my work phone rang—my client, Mrs. Patel, was calling about a confusing line item on her invoice. She expected clear, prompt communication, and I knew she was already frustrated by the delay. I stared at both screens, feeling the pressure build in my chest. If I answered Sam, I’d risk missing Mrs. Patel and looking unprofessional. If I took the call, I’d be letting my brother down again, reinforcing his belief that I didn’t care. The demands of being a good sister and a reliable accountant pulled me in opposite directions, and I felt paralyzed, torn between the people who needed me in completely different ways.
